Award.AwardTitle: Evaluating the Accuracy of Biogeochemical Cycling Rates from Transient Tracers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ability to predict future oceanic uptake of carbon dioxide and, consequently, the response of the coupled ocean/land/atmosphere system to climate forcing, requires an understanding of both how the physical, chemical, and biological systems presently function and how they are likely to respond to predicted environmental changes. Oxygen consumption/utilization (OUR) and nutrient regeneration (NRR) rates in the ocean interior provide an attractive bottom-up approach to infer marine productivity in the sunlit surface waters. Oxygen utilization rates are often estimated using the distributions of "transient tracers,' compounds such as chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) that are introduced in to the atmosphere and oceans by human activity. Tracer-based estimates are subject to uncertainties based on several factors including the time history of the tracers and ocean mixing. Investigators at the University of Washington plan to use ocean models to examine the sources of these uncertainties and determine where in the oceans the tracer-based estimates agree best (and worst) with the actual rates. The investigation of biogeochemical cycling rates and surface ocean productivity based on tracer techniques will be put into context with those from other measurement systems such as satellite or Argo floats and will provide an improved view of biogeochemical cycling in the ocean. Recommendations on where the technique works will be important for the interpretation of results from future hydrographic cruises and can guide strategies for future tracer measurements. The investigators will include undergraduate summer students in the research, and participate in outreach programs in local schools.

The investigators will address the biases and uncertainties in the tracer-based OURs and NRRs using a multi-model approach. Analysis of existing tracer model output, including oxygen, phosphate, CFCs, SF6, ideal ages and transit time distributions (TTDs), will reveal in which regions and during which times transient tracer ages (combined with oxygen fields) give the best estimation of the known oxygen consumption terms in the model. They will expand this work using the National Center for Atmospheric Research's Parallel Ocean Program model output (ocean-only configuration) which contains a much larger variety of biogeochemical parameters and more complex biogeochemistry (though no SF6, TTDs or ideal age spun up to steady state). In addition to OURs, this allows investigation of the accuracy of tracer-inferred NRRs, including denitrification rates, silicate production rates, and calcium carbonate dissolution, as well as regeneration rates of dissolved organic nutrients. Finally, a planned, near-future addition of multi-biogeochemical tracer algorithms to the current offline will enable the investigators to look at complex biogeochemistry and the full spectrum of transient tracer, ideal, and TTD ages simultaneously. Finally they will address the robustness of apparent changes in OURs/NRRs observed during recent and upcoming Climate Variability and Prediction/Global Ocean Ship-based Hydrographic Investigations Program (CLIVAR/GO-SHIP) Repeat Hydrography (RH) sections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project evaluated an important method used to determine respiration in the ocean based on data from below the surface mixed layer. The approach taken involved simulating the respective data (oxygen measurements, and tracer ages) in two general circulation models with model grids that cover the global ocean (i.e. all oceans) and ~50 layers in the vertical. The models have modules to simulate not only physical ocean variables (temperature, salinity, density, water velocity), but also ocean biogeochemistry (oxygen, nutrients, and dye-like transient ocean circulation tracers, such as chlorofluorocarbons, CFCs, and sulfur hexafluoride, SF6, also found in the real world).

The idea is that the oxygen consumption term (=net respiration) at every grid point at depth in the biogeochemical model can be compared to the oxygen utilization rate (OUR) inferred from Oxygen (O2) gradients relative to CFC/SF6-based water age gradients in the model. These tracer ages are estimates of the time elapsed since water left the surface ocean. Comparison of the OURs with the net respiration in the model gives an indication how well OURs inferred from real ocean data represent the true amount of respiration happening in the ocean. Knowing the latter is important because, integrated over the subsurface water column, respiration gives an estimate how much organic carbon (=food for remineralization, fueling and proportional to respiration) is exported from the surface ocean through sinking particles and in dissolved form and thus how strong this portion of the carbon cycle is in different ocean basins.

Summer undergraduate students (two) and two postdocs participated in the project in order to foster STEM education and to train the next generation of geosciences researchers.

This project provides groundwork to help define how the ocean carbon cycle presently functions and how it will respond to climate change and increased carbon emissions, including ocean warming and enhanced oceanic CO2 uptake, as determined by future ocean data collections. However, we find that OUR estimates from O2 and tracer ages are not always accurate representations of respiration and that over large parts of the oceans the OUR method underestimates how much oxygen is consumed and thus how much organic carbon is exported from the surface. This has to do to some extent with inaccuracies in the water age determination from transient tracer (CFC/SF6) measurements, but even more so with biases that affect the OUR method due to ocean mixing present everywhere. Only in regions close to where water is subducted from the mixed layer into the subsurface ocean, nominally at the poleward sides of the subtropical gyres of the Pacific, Atlantic and Indian Oceans, we find that the OUR method gives a reasonable representation of oxygen consumption.

The conclusions from this project are 1.) that the OUR method can be applied over large spans of the ocean due to tracer (and oxygen) data collected from a network of ocean sections, 2.) that it is relatively accurate in newly ventilated waters, i.e. in young water recently subducted from the mixed layer, and  3.) that these tracer-based estimates provide a lower limit for ocean carbon export otherwise, globally and on basin-scale, in particular in the Indian and Atlantic Ocean where we had applied the method to data to determine organic carbon cycling. For the future, we suggest 1.) that evaluation of repeat ocean data is particular useful in newly subducted waters to see whether OURs and carbon export maybe changing in response to climate change and 2.) that in particular an increase in OURs indicates a true change in carbon export (an increase) because the biases in tracer ages and the OUR method are such that they produce a decrease in OUR over time resulting from the time-variant transient nature of the tracers (and not from true ocean changes in circulation and/or carbon cycling).
